29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up,
we put a disabled shooter in touch with JCB

36.text:
so he can shoot pheasants for the first time.
Do you have an unruly puppy? We have a gun

42.text:
dog training series. First, the legend that
is Roy Lupton.

48.text:
There's plenty of the white stuff in this
week's programme. Here in Hampshire at the

54.text:
Steventon shoot it's 6 inches deep. We're
out to film Roy on a pheasant shoot, something

59.text:
we've never done before. We're not altogether
sure he understands that a shotgun is meant

65.text:
for shooting birds in the air and not incoming
foxes. Hey-ho - let's see if he gets booted

72.text:
off on the first drive for concentrating on
ground game.

76.text:
Roy is a guest of Keith Goresuch - they've
swapped and shared some stalking outings over

81.text:
the past few years. Keith has kindly offered
Roy the chance to join his friends and family

87.text: day, but Roy's feeling a bit rusty.

89.text:
Whenever I get out on a stand, especially
after being out of the game for so long the

95.text:
old butterflies are kicking really badly.
I definitely think I will need a bit of luck

102.text:
on this one. It is just absolutely amazing
the feeling you get out and are on the stand

108.text:
and everything goes live and you are ready
to begin. It doesn't matter how much you have

112.text: done it, it still gets exciting.

114.text:
On the next peg down is George with his "caddy".
This dedicated clay shot is having his first

120.text:
pop at game shooting so has a friend to talk
him through it. More about George later.

125.text:
On with the show - and the higher numbered
pegs and the walking gun get the most of the

129.text:
shooting on this drive. Roy gets off the mark.
He can now start to enjoy the day.

135.text:
Now that was brilliant. When you think that
we are a week away from the end of the season

139.text:
that was phenomenal the amount of birds that
were still showing. So I think the keeper

144.text:
is going to be very happy with the show that
they got here. I know that they have got a

147.text:
few more days to finish off, but they really
can't complain about that.

150.text:
As Roy has got his eye in - we try and hinder
him by strapping a Go-Pro camera to the end

155.text:
of his barrel. It ain't pretty but we get
the odd shot.

178.text:
There are some good shots here today - Alan
next door is a gamekeeper and shows us how

184.text:
Drive three is a short walk but the beaters
have a way to come. When they do, Roy picks

190.text:
some nice birds and some that need finishing
off.

192.text:
With that bird there it is not what you would
call a sporting bird, but she had been hit

198.text:
by one of the guns standing in front and so
just administered the coup de grace.

206.text:
Roy also illustrates the most efficient way
of using both barrels.

213.text:
He remains calm refusing to show any emotion
- and this is something you notice all across

218.text:
the country - that cool calm exterior of a
gun who's made a great shot. Inside it's a

233.text:
Time for elevenses and a chance to get to
know our fellow guns. There is a mixed bag

240.text: First day out on game today?

242.text:
It is indeed. I have been shooting for some
20 odd years clay pigeons and I will say to

247.text:
you it somewhat different between clay pigeons
and the live bird.

253.text:
Have you found it more tricky getting onto
the bird from the clay pigeons or is it?

257.text:
I shoot down the line which are all going
away birds and of course you have got the

260.text:
incomers in so you have got the crossers.
So yes there is a variety, but what does put

265.text:
you off is that little black eye looking at
you. They don't do that with clay and when

269.text:
you miss it in clay shooting they say lost.
Nobody calls out here do they? The actual

277.text: That is it. Comradery is part of it.

280.text:
Absolutely brilliant. Yes at ten years old
had an air rifle shot at a sparrow, winged

286.text:
it, felt quite bad about that. I hadn't shot
since until today and I was interested to

296.text:
see my reactions once I shot the first clay,
you are right, first bird. Yes, fine no problem.

303.text: Ok so your conscience is fine at the moment.

306.text:
The adrenaline flows and that is something
that surprised me, because yes, you shoot

310.text:
at clays and if you are in it to get a silver
cup then that makes the adrenaline go. That

314.text:
is just shooting the clay, there is no emotion
in that because that is what it is all about.

318.text: But this because it is live.

320.text:
Roy's next peg requires some fast reactions
- the birds aren't low but they scoot over

325.text: the ride offering only a small window of opportunity.

329.text:
There are clearly still plenty of birds about,
even at this time of year, and it sounds like

333.text: the guns have enjoyed a good season.

334.text:
So are you happy with the way the shooting
has gone this year?

337.text:
It has been very good. We have thoroughly
enjoyed it and I think most of the teams of

341.text:
So they have all gone away with a smile on
their faces.

343.text:
Yes, yes. Given it is January there are plenty
of birds and in actual fact in terms of ...we

349.text: have got two different strains of bird here.

353.text:
The Kansas is the bird and we have got a three
quarters cross and a pure Kansas. Believe

360.text:
it or not we have actually tagged them with
different coloured tags to see if we can determine

365.text:
which fly better and which hold better. Things
that game keepers are very interested in.

370.text:
Because obviously that is your other side,
you are on a game farm as well.

373.text:
Yes, it is the first year we have flown them
and three other estates actually bought them

378.text:
from us this year as well. The reports we
got back from the keepers from all of the

381.text:
other three estates have said they have held
brilliantly and flown brilliantly and in fact

386.text:
they already know that they want the same
for next year.

389.text:
With darkness always an issue at this time
of year we power through the next few drives

393.text:
looking to have a late lunch. Talking of food,
Roy's convalescence from his op meant he's

398.text:
put on a few pounds which is why he is not
wearing his breeks today - more importantly

403.text: it does affect the fit of the gun.

406.text:
All joking aside I have found that when you
put on a few pounds or lose a few pounds,

411.text:
the fit to the gun can change. Just because
you had a gun that fitted beforehand doesn't

421.text:
necessarily mean it will continue to do so
if you become a little fat porker, like I

428.text:
Even with the extra padding Roy and the rest
of the guns shoot well and a good day is had

432.text:
by all with a bag of 228 - most of which ended
up in the back of Roy's truck - best leave

439.text:
off that gun fitting for a few months yet
Mr Lupton.

443.text:
For more information about the Steventon shoot,
go to SportingGameServices.co.uk.

451.text:
Now from one old stager to another, it's David
on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

465.text:
David Cameron's plans for a high speed rail
link could be more damaging to the hunting,

470.text:
shooting and fishing than Tony Blair's ban
on hound sports. That's the conclusion of

476.text:
backbench Tory MPs who represent rural constituencies
in the path of the £30 billion scheme to

482.text:
cut 30 minutes off the rail journey between
London and Leeds, and London and Manchester.

487.text:
If your hunt country, shoot or local river
is going to be affected, please get in touch

493.text:
The proposal to build a barrage across the
river Severn has been described as a 24/7

499.text:
fish mincing machine. The Angling Trust has
joined the Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust and the

505.text:
RSPB to come out strongly against the plans.
The Trust's National Campaigns Coordinator

511.text:
and former Labour MP Martin Salter says that
the groups support tidal energy development

515.text:
in the Severn, but that the current proposal
will lead to fish deaths due to sudden changes

519.text:
in water pressure and salinity, and through
turbine strikes.

525.text:
Winter can be a perilous time as this American
deer found out. The mule deer was caught out

530.text:
after wandering onto a frozen-over lake in
Golden, Colorado in the US. The buck was stranded

536.text:
on the ice as it struggled to stand up. Rescuers
eventually threw a rope round its antlers

543.text:
The summer clay shooting competition season
is underway at the Royal Berkshire Shooting

549.text:
School. Its Handicap Classic runs until the
final on 7th May and there are now £14,000

554.text:
of prizes. If you are watching this on YouTube,
click on the screen to see our film about

559.text:
it. Meanwhile West Midlands Shooting Ground
in Shropshire is getting ready for one of

563.text:
the high points of the semi-auto owner's year,
the Benelli SP'Auto Championships on Sunday

569.text:
19th May. Click on the screen to see our film
about that.

573.text:
And finally, cats famously have nine lives.
Foxes are not so lucky, especially not this

581.text:
one, who is ignoring the advice of his friends
the crows. Viewer John Wilkes sent in this

586.text:
film, which is doing the rounds on the internet,
of what must be the unluckiest fox there was.

592.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

605.text:
Thank you David. Now Chris Warner shoots clay
pigeons from a wheelchair and is keen to try

610.text: pheasants. JCB rides to the rescue.

614.text:
We're in snowy Hertfordshire today to provide
Chris Warner with his first day's pheasant

620.text:
shooting. Chris has shot plenty of clays and
is keen to transfer those skills to the pheasants.

626.text:
His wheelchair, however, isn't quite up to
the off road trials of a pheasant shoot. Local

633.text:
JCB dealer MK Agriculture is lending a JCB
Workmax and even better Andy is Chris's driver

641.text:
This machine we have got here we are going
to be using today to transport Chris around

645.text:
the shoot and get him through all the sticky
and awkward situations we might come across

651.text:
where we need to go. This vehicle here is
equipped with a front opening windscreen which

656.text:
is quite useful for shooting out of the front
of. Rifling and things like that. It is a

661.text:
four wheeled drive machine with a diff lock,
so should handle most of the sticky situations.

665.text:
It is equipped in the back with game carriers.
This is the smaller of the range of game carriers

674.text:
as we can carry roughly 60 brace of game on
here. It has opening sides to keep the game

681.text:
cool and dry. So I am hoping we will have
a fantastic day and Chris will really enjoy

688.text:
The guns start to gather at the Colne Spring
House shoot and, although the weather is bleak,

692.text:
the company is in good spirits. Chris is eager
to make a start.

696.text:
I have never done any game shooting before.
This is my first game shoot. I am really looking

701.text:
forward to it. It is nice to be able to come
out and do this. I always felt it would be

709.text: difficult for me in a wheelchair to do that.

712.text:
The shooting at Colne Spring House is run
by gamekeeper Peter Jones. He's a well known

716.text:
character in the shooting industry and his
son Vinnie is well known for all sorts of

722.text:
Off we go, everyone in to the buses and Chris
riding shotgun in the Workmax.

736.text:
Drive Number 1, Chris is in position and ready
to go. The pheasants not so much. They're

741.text: still waiting on their morning coffee.

744.text:
The beaters close in and up they go only to
come straight back down as Chris bags his

753.text:
The first stand is a success all round and
the Workmax has its work cut out as the pheasants

759.text: are piled high on the Gamemate.

762.text:
On to the second drive and Chris isn't so
successful, but he's exactly where he's wanted

772.text:
At least the dogs and pheasants are getting
acquainted. Drinks time and at this time of

777.text:
year an essential pitstop to fend off the
frost bite. It's a bit of a trek to the next

781.text: drive, but that's no trouble for the Workmax.

788.text:
The pheasants are reluctant to get going on
the third, and who can blame them? It's freezing

793.text:
today but it's amazing how quickly you warm
up when the birds start moving.

797.text:
Wait - here they come. A torrent of pheasants
appear and Chris is blasting left, right and

812.text:
Another couple for Chris' bag and that seems
like a convenient time to stop for lunch.

816.text: To save time Peter hosts it in the bus -

820.text:
Unfortunately not all the vehicles are coping
with the elements - There seems to be engine

826.text:
Not to worry. Annie, Peter's daughter, keeps
the guns entertained on the way to the next

833.text:
It's out of the woods and into the open for
the penultimate drive. The guns line up in

838.text:
There are partridge galore on this drive.
The pheasants get off lucky and Chris has

842.text:
another species to add to his game card. It's
been such a successful day that the bird quota

848.text:
has already been filled. With the failing
light, Peter decides it's best to call it

853.text:
a day and tell us a little more about his
sporting family.

856.text:
I brought the kids up on here, 1973 and taught
them to drive landrovers from about five years

864.text:
old and Annie and Vin are still coming over.
Annie beats with her three little dogs and

873.text:
as Vin says it has been emotional. But today
has been good, great fun and we managed to

881.text:
get Chris about everywhere which was great.
I really had to think that one because getting

885.text:
him into the wood where there are ditches
all around, but we actually overcame that.

890.text:
Everybody was absolutely delighted and we
only did four drives.

895.text:
In the lodge everyone is defrosting in front
of the fire and it's a chance for a cuppa

900.text:
I would just like to thank everybody for what
you have done and for makingvit so enjoyable

906.text: for him. Thank you very much.

907.text:
Chris's first day pheasant shooting is not
going to be his last.

911.text:
Everybody who put the shoot on they couldn't
have done enough for me, especially with JCB,

917.text:
with what they lent us. That helped me I wouldn't
have been able to do it without that. But

925.text:
I wouldn't have been able to do it without
all the guys here at the shoot either.

928.text:
The JCB has meant Chris has been given access
all areas and it's been a fantastic opportunity

933.text:
for all to show that with a bit of effort
a game day is an option for one and all.

939.text:
Now to get your gun dog to a perfect pitch
it is our new gun dog training series.

949.text:
A bird lands out of sight of your dog and,
as far as the retrieve is concerned, your

959.text:
dog and often you are flying blind. Here are
top gundog trainer Ricky Moloney's training

968.text:
First retrieve, end gun or a gun further down
shot it, dog hasn't seen any of that retrieve

975.text:
what so ever, so he has got to believe me
that he goes out and he runs until he either

980.text:
finds the game, touches scent, or until I
say woh that is the area I want you to settle

987.text:
Ok show me the command that means this is
the line.

991.text:
So if I am lining my dog up, one hand, line
the dog up, go back. That is the command I

998.text:
give the dog. It comes down to foot work and
heel work. I have trained my dog about heel

1003.text:
work. Where ever I am as a retriever he want
to be at the side of me. So whenever I turn

1008.text:
with the gun, the dog is in a line and I can
then go back, if it has seen it just gets

1014.text:
If the dog comes off the line do you then
call it back and start again?

1018.text:
Depends on the dog, it depends on the dog's
temperament. If you have got a very sensitive

1021.text:
dog and you keep calling it back you could
get it very sticky. He would go out five yards

1027.text:
and stop and look at you, am I doing the right
thing am I coming back. So dog training is

1031.text:
really about looking at the type of dog you
have got, from eight weeks when you acquire

1036.text:
it as a puppy and assessing that dog, seeing
how he ticks, whether it is bold, whether

1040.text:
it is shy, or in between. Whether it is hard
hunting, whether it is a dog that runs in

1045.text:
a straight line naturally. Then you will tailor
your training according to the puppy, the

1051.text: youngster you have got in front of you.

1055.text: The second retrieve, nice shot, well done.

1058.text:
The second retrieve it landed and it ran.
You are disconnecting with the dog, the moment

1063.text:
it has gone over the wall aren't you? It is
not listening to you it is going straight

1068.text:
The dog has got to deal with that, that is
what I have got a dog for. Too much handling,

1072.text:
too much over training you get a dog that
might touch that fall, but not follow it up.

1078.text: So the art in training a good dog is balance.

1081.text:
Ricky Moloney runs Ribblesdale Labradors.
This series on gundog training tips is brought

1086.text:
to you by Skinners Petfoods, maker of the
Field & Trial range of gundog feeds. Visit

1095.text:
From gun dogs to the wider world of hunting
on the internet. It is Hunting YouTube.

1102.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1107.text:
We've been away - sorry about that - lots
of your suggestions to catch up with. The

1111.text:
first is Ireland's most outward-facing shooting
group. Invited to Ballynatray Estate in Co

1116.text:
Cork by the Irish Hawking Club, TheRathcormacGunClub
presents Goshawk Hunting in Ireland. Tricky

1121.text:
thing to film, hawking, but they get good
action nonetheless.

1125.text:
Stuart Taylor sends us his video of Gun cam
pigeon shooting on rape and in woods on the

1129.text:
auspicious 12th December last year, 12/12/12.
He was out with his dad and they got a few.

1135.text:
Now, we have uncovered the Tommy Cooper of
shooting videos. FurOnTheGround attempts to

1140.text:
make his own scope cam out of sticky-backed
plastic and a pair of Val's old knickers,

1144.text:
with hilarious consequences. In case you wondered
what the blurry white target is, it's Frosty

1148.text:
the Snowman in FurOnTheGround's garden. Happily,
FurOnThe Ground is able to laugh at himself.

1154.text:
From Tommy Cooper to Ant and Dec. Carl and
Alex Smith have shot to stardom in Anglers'

1159.text:
Mail magazine as no-nonsense teenagers devoted
to coarse angling. They turn up on AnglersMailTV

1164.text:
and on their own channel called, unsurprisingly,
CarlandAlex Smith. In this film, Carl or Alex

1169.text:
is out feeder fishing for bream and small
stream roach, and he catches a goldfish.

1174.text:
Now we get numerous requests for films from
EdgunUSA and here's an unuusal one that finds

1179.text:
its way into the angling double we like to
put in the middle of Hunting YouTube. Ted

1183.text:
the Edgun, the God of Airguns and supreme
being of holdover is in the Bahamas spearfishing,

1188.text: and of course it is a great film.

1192.text:
FatGuyWithAKatana sends us Motohumter's Bike
hog hunting with the message: ‘I think this

1196.text:
guy could use some more views. He's tearing
up the Australian Outback in pursuit of feral

1200.text:
hogs armed with a dirtbike, a helmet cam and
a Beretta 92'. And so he is, catching a pig

1205.text:
with his bare hands in this film. For reference,
Motohumter's five steps to biking a boar are:

1210.text:
1 choose the biggest boar, 2 bend him from
the rough terrain of the gully, 3 outpace

1215.text:
him, 4 wrap him up, and 5 throw and pin him.
Much the same advice is offered to the Wallabies

1222.text:
This next film is a challenge. It's an interview
with Franz Albrecht von Oettingen who is the

1226.text:
George Digweed of wild boar shooting, only
younger and, with the light behind him, slightly

1231.text:
better looking. OK - he's the pin-up pop star
of continental hunting. He appears in the

1234.text:
Hunters Video Wild Boar Fever film where he
shoots seven in a row. If you don't speak

1238.text:
German and you want to watch this film, you
will need to turn on not just YouTube's automatic

1242.text:
subtitles but also its automatic subtitles
translation feature, which turn the interview

1247.text:
from inexplicable to sidesplittingly inexplicable,
but you will above all get to see some truly

1251.text:
astonishing shooting. And he's not even 30
years old. Makes you spit.

1255.text:
Finally, a viewer wants to highlight the work
of the channel ClassicBowHunts which, a bit

1259.text:
like the Caves of Lascaux, is posting ancient
hunting library footage in order to preserve

1264.text:
it. This film is called Bill Negley Elephant
Bow Hunt. Bill Negley was out after elephants

1268.text:
in the 1950s with a recurve bow. It wasn't
great for the elephants but it's near the

1272.text:
top of the list of things they said could
not be done.

1275.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1278.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1285.text:
Well we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube don't hesitate to

1288.text:
hit the subscribe button that is somewhere
round the outside of the screen there, or

1292.text:
go to our webpage www.fieldsportschannel.tv
where you can click to like us on Facebook,

1296.text:
or follow us on Twitter, or scroll down to
the bottom of the page. Pop your email address

1300.text:
into our constant contact box and we will
contact you about our programme,which is out

1304.text:
7pm UK time every Wednesday. This has been
Fieldsports Britain.
